content: Medical malpractice insurance has been a topic of congressional attention during crisis periods in the mid-1970s, mid-1980s, and early 2000s due to sharp increases in physicians' liability insurance premiums, difficulties in finding coverage, and reports of physicians leaving areas or retiring. Public policy measures were implemented at state and federal levels to address market disruptions, but attention receded as premium increases moderated and market conditions improved over time. In some areas, insurers withdrew coverage, leading to physicians leaving or retiring due to insurance difficulties.
